items.title: Trump declaration of Greenland framework deal met with scepticism amid tariff relief
items.standfirst: Nato chief Mark Rutte says there is ‚Äòa lot of work to be done‚Äô, as some Danish MPs voice concern at Greenland apparently being sidelined in US president‚Äôs talks Donald Trump‚Äôs announcement of a ‚Äúframework of a future deal‚Äù that would settle the issue of Greenland after weeks of escalating threats has been met with profound scepticism from people in the Arctic territory, even as financial markets rebounded and European leaders welcomed a reprieve from further tariffs.Just hours after the president used his speech at the World Economic Forum to insist he wanted Greenland, ‚Äúincluding right, title and ownership,‚Äù but backed away from his more bellicose threats of military intervention ‚Äì Trump took to social media to announce ‚Äúthe framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland‚Äù and withdrew the threat of tariffs against eight European countries. He later called it ‚Äúa concept of a deal‚Äù when he spoke to business network CNBC soon after Wall Street closed. Continue reading...
items.content: Nato chief Mark Rutte says there is ‚Äòa lot of work to be done‚Äô, as some Danish MPs voice concern at Greenland apparently being sidelined in US president‚Äôs talks Donald Trump‚Äôs announcement of a ‚Äúframework of a future deal‚Äù that would settle the issue of Greenland after weeks of escalating threats has been met with profound scepticism from people in the Arctic territory, even as financial markets rebounded and European leaders welcomed a reprieve from further tariffs.Just hours after the president used his speech at the World Economic Forum to insist he wanted Greenland, ‚Äúincluding right, title and ownership,‚Äù but backed away from his more bellicose threats of military intervention ‚Äì Trump took to social media to announce ‚Äúthe framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland‚Äù and withdrew the threat of tariffs against eight European countries. He later called it ‚Äúa concept of a deal‚Äù when he spoke to business network CNBC soon after Wall Street closed. Continue reading...

items.title: Many Greenlanders still uneasy after Trump's draft deal
items.standfirst: Many Greenlanders remain uneasy after President Donald Trump withdrew his threat to impose new tariffs on European nations and announced a ‚Äúframework‚Äù of a NATO deal on the territory, which he promises will be a great deal for everybody. NBC News‚Äô Ellison Barber spoke with Greenlanders about their reactions and concerns regarding Greenland‚Äôs future.

items.title: Kindergartener brings 100-year-old great grandpa to 100th day of school
items.standfirst: With many kindergarteners celebrating the 100th day of school by bringing 100 things to class, one little girl in Georgia brought just one very special thing -- her 100-year-old great-grandfather. Tony Dokoupil has the story.
items.content: With many kindergarteners celebrating the 100th day of school by bringing 100 things to class, one little girl in Georgia brought just one very special thing -- her 100-year-old great-grandfather. Tony Dokoupil has the story.

items.title: Trump backs off from tariff threat over Greenland
items.standfirst: President Trump said he will not be imposing tariffs against European countries over their objections to his efforts to acquire Greenland‚Äã.
items.content: President Trump said he will not be imposing tariffs against European countries over their objections to his efforts to acquire Greenland‚Äã.

items.title: House panel advances contempt charges against Clintons over Epstein probe
items.standfirst: A Republican-led House committee voted on Wednesday to advance contempt of Congress charges against former president Bill Clinton and former secretary of state Hillary Clinton for denying a congressional subpoena over the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. In a rare break from party lines, several progressive lawmakers supported the move, citing the need for full transparency in the Epstein probe.
items.content: A Republican-led House committee voted on Wednesday to advance contempt of Congress charges against former president Bill Clinton and former secretary of state Hillary Clinton for denying a congressional subpoena over the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. In a rare break from party lines, several progressive lawmakers supported the move, citing the need for full transparency in the Epstein probe.

items.title: Trump touts potential Greenland deal agreed with NATO chief
items.standfirst: After a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, President Trump told reporters in Davos that an ‚Äúultimate long-term deal‚Äù for Greenland was in the making that would be ‚Äúreally fantastic for the U.S.A.‚Äù
items.content: After a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, President Trump told reporters in Davos that an ‚Äúultimate long-term deal‚Äù for Greenland was in the making that would be ‚Äúreally fantastic for the U.S.A.‚Äù

items.title: In Davos speech, Trump ruled out using military force to acquire Greenland
items.standfirst: During a speech in Davos, Switzerland, President Trump ruled out using military force to acquire Greenland. But he left many questions about the U.S. role in the world.
items.content: During a speech in Davos, Switzerland, President Trump ruled out using military force to acquire Greenland. But he left many questions about the U.S. role in the world.

items.title: Trump cancels threatened tariffs after reaching 'framework of deal' on Greenland
items.standfirst: Just hours after he doubled down on his claim that the US should "get Greenland", Donald Trump made an abrupt U-turn on the tariffs he had threatened to slap on European nations that opposed his bid. Announcing on his Truth Social platform, the US president said he and NATO chief Mark Rutte had reached a "framework of a future deal" on Greenland, and that in light of that, he would not be imposing the 10% import duties that were slated to go into effect on February 1st.
items.content: Just hours after he doubled down on his claim that the US should "get Greenland", Donald Trump made an abrupt U-turn on the tariffs he had threatened to slap on European nations that opposed his bid. Announcing on his Truth Social platform, the US president said he and NATO chief Mark Rutte had reached a "framework of a future deal" on Greenland, and that in light of that, he would not be imposing the 10% import duties that were slated to go into effect on February 1st.

items.title: Trump cancels tariff threat, says NATO's Rutte agreed to Greenland deal 'framework'
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Wednesday withdrew ‚Å†a threat to impose tariffs on eight European nations for ‚Äçtheir opposition to his ambitions for US ownership of Greenland, saying he had reached the outlines of a deal with NATO General Secretary Mark Rutte on the Danish autonomous territory‚Äôs future. He did not give any details of what he described as ‚Äúthe framework of a future deal‚Äù.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Wednesday withdrew ‚Å†a threat to impose tariffs on eight European nations for ‚Äçtheir opposition to his ambitions for US ownership of Greenland, saying he had reached the outlines of a deal with NATO General Secretary Mark Rutte on the Danish autonomous territory‚Äôs future. He did not give any details of what he described as ‚Äúthe framework of a future deal‚Äù.

items.title: House Oversight panel votes to hold Bill and Hillary Clinton in contempt of Congress
items.standfirst: Republicans on the committee have been seeking to question the Clintons as part of a probe into the government's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. The vote sends the matter to the full House.
items.content: Republicans on the committee have been seeking to question the Clintons as part of a probe into the government's handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case. The vote sends the matter to the full House. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

items.title: NATO chief Rutte 'may have explained to Trump existing US rights in Greenland'
items.standfirst: 'There really are no substantive concessions that Mark Rutte could have given Trump', FRANCE 24's Brussels correspondent Dave Keating explains, adding that the NATO chief may 'have just explained to Trump the existing rights that the US has in Greenland and sold this to Trump as something new'. Trump cancelled his tariff threat on several European nations after coming to terms with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte on a ‚Äúframework of a future deal‚Äù on Arctic security.
items.content: 'There really are no substantive concessions that Mark Rutte could have given Trump', FRANCE 24's Brussels correspondent Dave Keating explains, adding that the NATO chief may 'have just explained to Trump the existing rights that the US has in Greenland and sold this to Trump as something new'. Trump cancelled his tariff threat on several European nations after coming to terms with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte on a ‚Äúframework of a future deal‚Äù on Arctic security.

items.title: Trump says agreed 'framework' for US deal over Greenland
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Wednesday he had reached a framework for a deal over Greenland following a meeting with NATO chief Mark Rutte, and that he would therefore waive tariffs scheduled to hit European allies. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said Wednesday he had reached a framework for a deal over Greenland following a meeting with NATO chief Mark Rutte, and that he would therefore waive tariffs scheduled to hit European allies. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.

Trump tells Davos he won‚Äôt use force to take Greenland
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump insisted he wants to ‚Äúget Greenland, including right, title and ownership,‚Äù but he said he wouldn‚Äôt employ force to achieve that ‚Äî using his speech Wednesday at the World Economic Forum to repeatedly deride European allies and vow that NATO shouldn‚Äôt stand in the way of U.S. expansionism.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump insisted he wants to ‚Äúget Greenland, including right, title and ownership,‚Äù but he said he wouldn‚Äôt employ force to achieve that ‚Äî using his speech Wednesday at the World Economic Forum to repeatedly deride European allies and vow that NATO shouldn‚Äôt stand in the way of U.S. expansionism.

items.title: Trump steps up Greenland annexation demand and attacks European leaders at Davos
items.standfirst: US president tells business and political leaders in Davos his country needs ownership to defend ‚Äòunsecured island‚ÄôTrump news at a glance: at Davos, president rambles, backs down and touts ‚Äòfuture deal‚Äô on GreenlandDonald Trump has stepped up his demand to annex Greenland but said the US would not use force to seize it during a rambling, invective-laden speech at Davos where he again lashed out at Europe‚Äôs political leaders.Trump gave his speech as they sought to avert a full-scale crisis over Greenland ‚Äì an effort that appeared successful later as the US president suddenly announced he would delay imposing tariffs on eight European countries from 1 February as negotiations continue. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli fire strikes journalists and children in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli forces on Wednesday killed at least 11 Palestinians in Gaza, including two boys, three journalists and a woman, hospitals said, on one of the enclave 's deadliest days since the ceasefire took effect.
items.content: Israeli forces on Wednesday killed at least 11 Palestinians in Gaza, including two boys, three journalists and a woman, hospitals said, on one of the enclave 's deadliest days since the ceasefire took effect.(Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

items.title: 3 journalists killed in Gaza, including cameraman who worked with CBS News
items.standfirst: An Israeli airstrike killed three journalists in Gaza on Wednesday, the territory's civil defense agency said. One of those killed, Abed Shaat, had worked for years as a cameraman for CBS News and other outlets.
items.content: An Israeli airstrike killed three journalists in Gaza on Wednesday, the territory's civil defense agency said. One of those killed, Abed Shaat, had worked for years as a cameraman for CBS News and other outlets.

The justice department‚Äôs office of the‚Ä¶

Holmes was convicted in 2022 and reported to a federal prison in‚Ä¶

Holmes was convicted in 2022 and reported to a federal prison in‚Ä¶

items.title: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes asks Trump for early release from prison
items.standfirst: Elizabeth Holmes, the former Theranos founder, has asked US President Donald Trump to release her from prison, with nearly six years still remaining on her sentence. Holmes‚Äô request for commutation follows her 2022 conviction on wire fraud and conspiracy charges, and comes after a federal appeals court upheld her 11-year sentence earlier this year.
items.content: Elizabeth Holmes, the former Theranos founder, has asked US President Donald Trump to release her from prison, with nearly six years still remaining on her sentence. Holmes‚Äô request for commutation follows her 2022 conviction on wire fraud and conspiracy charges, and comes after a federal appeals court upheld her 11-year sentence earlier this year.

items.standfirst: Conservative and liberal judges questioned administration over president‚Äôs authority to fire without due processUS politics ‚Äì live updatesUS supreme court justices appeared skeptical of Donald Trump‚Äôs case for firing a Federal Reserve governor on Wednesday, in a key test of the president‚Äôs power ‚Äì and his administration‚Äôs battle to exert greater control over the US central bank.Five months after Trump tried to fire Lisa Cook over apparent discrepancies on mortgage applications his officials claim are evidence of fraud, both conservative and liberal justices grilled the administration over whether the US president has the power to fire a Fed governor with seemingly no process. items.title: Bezos' Blue Origin announces satellite rival to Musk's Starlink
items.standfirst: Blue Origin will be focused on businesses and governments, while Starlink also offers services to individual customers.
items.content: Blue Origin will be focused on businesses and governments, while Starlink also offers services to individual customers.

items.title: Hand shape in Indonesian cave may be world‚Äôs oldest known rock art
items.standfirst: Archaeologists say stencil painted with ochre in limestone cave on Muna Island was created at least 67,800 years agoThe faded outline of a hand on a cave wall in Indonesia may be the world‚Äôs oldest known rock art, according to archaeologists who say it was created at least 67,800 years ago.The ancient hand stencil was discovered in a limestone cave popular with tourists on Muna Island, part of south-eastern Sulawesi, where it had gone unnoticed between more recent paintings of animals and other figures. Continue reading...

items.title: Kurds march in Iraqi Kurdistan against Syrian government takeover of minority
items.standfirst: Syria's government said a drone strike by the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces killed seven of its soldiers on Wednesday, though the ‚Å†SDF denied this, in an incident that threatens to derail a ceasefire after days of fighting in the northeast. In Erbil, Iraqi Kurds took to the streets to protest as Syrian Kurds see years of Kurdish de facto autonomy in the northeast vanish as Syrian forces take over.
items.content: Syria's government said a drone strike by the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces killed seven of its soldiers on Wednesday, though the ‚Å†SDF denied this, in an incident that threatens to derail a ceasefire after days of fighting in the northeast. In Erbil, Iraqi Kurds took to the streets to protest as Syrian Kurds see years of Kurdish de facto autonomy in the northeast vanish as Syrian forces take over.

items.title: Syrian army takes control of detention camp for Islamic State suspects
items.standfirst: Move follows withdrawal of Kurdish forces from al-Hawl, where 24,000 people are being held over alleged IS linksSyrian government forces have taken control of al-Hawl detention camp, which houses tens of thousands of suspected Islamic State members, after Kurdish forces withdrew.Soldiers entered the heavily fortified camp on Wednesday, part of a handover from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), which oversaw the camp for the last seven years, as the Syrian government vowed to secure the facility. Continue reading...
items.content: Move follows withdrawal of Kurdish forces from al-Hawl, where 24,000 people are being held over alleged IS linksSyrian government forces have taken control of al-Hawl detention camp, which houses tens of thousands of suspected Islamic State members, after Kurdish forces withdrew.Soldiers entered the heavily fortified camp on Wednesday, part of a handover from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), which oversaw the camp for the last seven years, as the Syrian government vowed to secure the facility. Continue reading...

items.title: Kurdish forces withdraw from IS detention camp in north-east Syria
items.standfirst: US says it no longer supports SDF, which left camp as it loses swathes of territory to government forcesKurdish-led forces in Syria have announced a withdrawal from a detention camp in north-east Syria housing tens of thousands of Islamic State-linked detainees, as the US declared it was no longer supporting them.The fate of al-Hawl, which houses among others the most radical foreign women suspected to have been members of IS and their families, is of great concern to neighbouring states and the international community. Continue reading...
items.content: US says it no longer supports SDF, which left camp as it loses swathes of territory to government forcesKurdish-led forces in Syria have announced a withdrawal from a detention camp in north-east Syria housing tens of thousands of Islamic State-linked detainees, as the US declared it was no longer supporting them.The fate of al-Hawl, which houses among others the most radical foreign women suspected to have been members of IS and their families, is of great concern to neighbouring states and the international community. items.content: The US pop superstar is among nine songwriters who have been inducted into the 2026 class.

items.title: 2026 Songwriters Hall of Fame inductees revealed on "CBS Mornings"
items.standfirst: The 2026 Songwriters Hall of Fame inductees were revealed on "CBS Mornings" on Wednesday. See the full list.
items.content: The 2026 Songwriters Hall of Fame inductees were revealed on "CBS Mornings" on Wednesday. See the full list.

clusters.title: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail
clusters.neutral_headline: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail

items.title: Colombia sentences ex-paramilitary leader Mancuso to 40 years in jail
items.standfirst: Salvatore Mancuso's group committed more than 100 crimes, many targeting an indigenous group, the tribunal ruled.
items.content: Salvatore Mancuso's group committed more than 100 crimes, many targeting an indigenous group, the tribunal ruled.

items.title: Colombian ex-paramilitary leader jailed for crimes against Indigenous groups
items.standfirst: Salvatore Mancuso given 40-year sentence, which could be reduced after truth and reparation activitiesA Colombian court has sentenced a former paramilitary leader to 40 years in prison for crimes committed against Indigenous communities in the province of La Guajira, including homicides, forced disappearances and the displacement of people from 2002 to 2006.The special tribunal that hears cases from the country‚Äôs armed conflict said in its ruling that Salvatore Mancuso was responsible for 117 crimes committed by fighters under his command in La Guajira. However, it added that Mancuso‚Äôs time in prison could be reduced to eight years, if he collaborated with truth and reparation activities that benefited victims of his former paramilitary group. Continue reading...
items.content: Salvatore Mancuso given 40-year sentence, which could be reduced after truth and reparation activitiesA Colombian court has sentenced a former paramilitary leader to 40 years in prison for crimes committed against Indigenous communities in the province of La Guajira, including homicides, forced disappearances and the displacement of people from 2002 to 2006.The special tribunal that hears cases from the country‚Äôs armed conflict said in its ruling that Salvatore Mancuso was responsible for 117 crimes committed by fighters under his command in La Guajira. However, it added that Mancuso‚Äôs time in prison could be reduced to eight years, if he collaborated with truth and reparation activities that benefited victims of his former paramilitary group.
